head.title: Electrosprayed Thylakoid–Alginate Film on a Micro-Pillar Electrode for Scalable Photosynthetic Energy Harvesting | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Electrosprayed Thylakoid–Alginate Film on a Micro-Pillar Electrode for Scalable Photosynthetic Energy Harvesting

Direct harvesting of electricity from photosynthesis is highly desired as an eco-friendly and sustainable energy harvesting technology. Photosynthetic apparatuses isolated from plants, such as thylakoid membranes (TMs), are deposited on an electrode by which photosynthetic electrons (PEs) are collected from water splitting. To enhance PE collection efficiency, it is critical to increase the electrochemical interfaces between TMs and the electrode. Considering the size of TMs to be around a few hundred nanometer, we hypothesize that an array of micropillar-shaped (MP) electrode can maximize the TM/electrode interface area. Thus, we developed MP electrodes with different heights and investigated the electrospraying of TM–alginate mixtures to fill the gaps between MPs uniformly and conformally. The uniformity of the TM–alginate film and the interaction between the TM and the MP electrode were evaluated to understand how the MP heights and film quality influenced the magnitude of the PE currents. PE currents increased up to 2.4 times for an MP electrode with an A/R of 1.8 compared to a flat electrode, indicating increased direct contact interface between TMs and the electrode. Furthermore, to demonstrate the scalability of this approach, an array of replicated SU-8 MP electrodes was prepared and PE currents of up to 3.2 μA were monitored without a mediator under 68 mW/cm2. Finally, the PE current harvesting was sustained for 14 days without decay, demonstrating the long-term stability of the TM–alginate biophotoanodes.

div.p:
Direct harvesting of electricity from photosynthesis is highly desired as an eco-friendly and sustainable energy harvesting technology. Photosynthetic apparatuses isolated from plants, such as thylakoid membranes (TMs), are deposited on an electrode by which photosynthetic electrons (PEs) are collected from water splitting. To enhance PE collection efficiency, it is critical to increase the electrochemical interfaces between TMs and the electrode. Considering the size of TMs to be around a few hundred nanometer, we hypothesize that an array of micropillar-shaped (MP) electrode can maximize the TM/electrode interface area. Thus, we developed MP electrodes with different heights and investigated the electrospraying of TM–alginate mixtures to fill the gaps between MPs uniformly and conformally. The uniformity of the TM–alginate film and the interaction between the TM and the MP electrode were evaluated to understand how the MP heights and film quality influenced the magnitude of the PE currents. PE currents increased up to 2.4 times for an MP electrode with an A/R of 1.8 compared to a flat electrode, indicating increased direct contact interface between TMs and the electrode. Furthermore, to demonstrate the scalability of this approach, an array of replicated SU-8 MP electrodes was prepared and PE currents of up to 3.2 μA were monitored without a mediator under 68 mW/cm
2
. Finally, the PE current harvesting was sustained for 14 days without decay, demonstrating the long-term stability of the TM–alginate biophotoanodes.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Due to environmental contamination by fossil fuel consumption and increased energy demand, there is an increased demand for eco-friendly and sustainable energy conversion technology.
(1)
In the past decades, photobioelectrochemical systems (PBEC) based on photosynthesis were extensively investigated, which converts solar energy to chemical energy.
(2)
Photosynthesis occurs in the thylakoid membrane (TM), an organelle inside the chloroplast of algal or plant cells, with a quantum efficiency approaching 100%.
(3)
Thus, PBEC exploiting photosynthetic whole cells or bacteria, or isolated photosynthetic apparatuses have promising potential of eco-friendly and sustainable energy production.

In the beginning of photosynthesis, water molecules split to oxygen, proton, and electrons by oxygen evolving complex in photosystem II (PS II) embedded in TMs. These electrons, photosynthetic electrons (PEs), are excited to high energy states by solar energy and electrochemically transferred from PS II to photosystem I (PS I) through the transmembrane proteins (e.g., plastoquinone pools, Cytochrome
b
6
f complexes) in electron transfer chain (ETC).
(4)
To extract the high energy PEs, various investigations were made with the whole cells such as cyanobacteria
(5,6)
and algal cells,
(7−11)
and the cellular or the subcellular photosynthetic apparatuses such as PS I,
(12,13)
PS II,
(14,15)
and TMs.
(16−28)
Extraction of PEs from the single
(8)
or multiple
(9)
algal cells were investigated by nanoelectrode insertion. Recent studies demonstrated the possibility of sustainable PBEC from the extraction of PEs during 7 days.
(10,11)
Although the whole-cell based PBECs have advantages such as having no need for an isolation process and long-duration operation, there are major drawbacks of limited scalability or need for mediators. As another approach, use of subcellular photosynthetic apparatus such as PS II or PS I, PE current density of up to ∼410 μA/cm
2
was achieved.
(14)
However, with the isolated subcellular apparatuses, the PE current rapidly decayed due to instability over time.
(29,30)

Contrary to that of isolated photosystems, the isolation and purification process of TMs is simple and inexpensive. In addition, it is possible to achieve greater stability through the maintenance of the intrinsic environment of subcellular apparatuses. Thus, TM-based PE harvesting has also been extensively studied. For effective transfer and collection of PE in TM biophotoanodes, PEs were extracted with the assistance of a soluble redox-mediator such as ferricyanide (K
3
Fe(CN)
6
),
(17,21,25)
quinones,
(26,27)
and osmium redox polymer ([Os(2,2′-bipyridine)
2
-poly(
N
-vinylimidazole)
10
Cl]
+/+2
),
(18,19,23,24)
or nanomaterials such as multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs)
(19,21,26)
and graphene oxide (GO).
(17,25,28)
Large PE current densities were achieved, up to a few hundred μA/cm
2
. In most cases, TM-based biophotoanodes were prepared by drop-casting because of its simplicity. TMs were deposited on a very small area of an electrode (typically <0.5 cm
2
) in many cases.
(18−23,27,28)
However, on a large electrode, since the thickness and distribution of drop-cast TMs were nonuniform, it is difficult to ensure reliable and repeatable performance of PBEC. In general, investigation of the biocompatibility and long-term sustainability of PBEC is still lacking. Thus, to further develop TM-based PBEC as a practical energy conversion application, it is crucial to achieve both scaled-up device fabrication and long-term stability of the TM biophotoanode.

In this work, we propose to achieve (i) enhanced PE extraction using micropillar (MP) electrodes, (ii) a large-scale biophotoanode with uniform deposition of TMs, and (iii) long-term and stable extraction of PEs using a TM–alginate film (
Figure
1
). To achieve enhanced PE extraction, a SU-8 MP electrode is fabricated from Si MP arrays as a master mold by a micromolding process. The dimension and electrochemical surface area (ECSA) of an SU-8 MP electrode is estimated to be similar to the values of an Si MP electrode. For uniform deposition of TMs on the surface of a large-scale MP electrode, electrospraying was employed. The uniformity and morphology of electrosprayed TMs is analyzed in comparison with drop-cast TMs. For optimization of the TM–alginate film on an SU-8 MP electrode, morphological interaction between the TM–alginate film and MP structures and the PE current in accordance with the film thickness are carefully monitored and analyzed. An enhanced PE current with a superposition effect is verified on a large-scale TM biophotoanode, and the PE current is monitored under various light intensities. Finally, direct extraction of PE from the TM-alg-MP electrode is sustained for 14 days without any significant decrease in PE currents

div.p: Figure 1. Extraction of photosynthetic electrons (PEs) from electrosprayed TM–alginate film on an SU-8 MP photoanode. A zoomed-in view shows direct extraction of PEs from the TM to the SU-8 MP electrode. Under illumination, water molecules are split on PS II reaction centers and the produced PEs are transported along the electron transfer chain of TMs; PEs can be extracted using an MP electrode with properly applied bias potentials.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3: 2.1. Fabrication and Characterization of SU-8 MP Electrode

div.div:
Si MP arrays were fabricated using ametal-assisted chemical etching (MACE) process, in which a silicon substrate underneath a metal catalyst layer was anisotropically etched (
Figure
2
a–c). A Si substrate below a gold (Au) patterned layer was selectively etched in a gently stirred etching solution containing HF, H
2
O
2
, and deionized (DI) water in a mixing ratio of 25:5:70, respectively. After the MACE process, the deposited Au pattern on the Si substrate was removed using a gold standard etchant solution. The Si MP arrays were fabricated to have 1 μm diameter and 2 μm pitch (center-to center) on a 1 × 1 cm
2
substrate (
Figure S1
of the
Supporting Information
,
SI
). Aspect ratios (A/R) of 1 and 1.8 for Si MP arrays were fabricated by varying the etching time for 5 and 7.5 min, respectively. As shown in
Figure
3
a-i,b-i, Si MP arrays with A/R of 1 and 1.8 were successfully fabricated by MACE process.

div.p: Figure 2. Fabrication of SU-8 MP electrode. (a) Photolithographically patterned Au layer deposited on Si substrate. (b) MACE process with Au layer as a catalyst. (c) Si MP arrays as a master mold after removal of metal layer. (d) PDMS mold from Si MP arrays. (e) SU-8 MP arrays replicated from PDMS mold. (f) SU-8 MP arrays replicated from Si MP arrays. (g) Surface coating of SU-8 MP arrays with 4-aminothiophenol (4-ATP) ethanol solution. (h) Au layer deposited by sputtering process.

Figure 3. SEM images of MP electrodes with different A/R; (a) 1 and (b) 1.8. All SEM images are shown in a 30° tilted view. (c) The average height of SU-8 MP electrode with each A/R (with 100 pillars). CV measurement to determine the electrochemical surface area (ECSA) with a different A/R of (d) Si MP electrodes and (e) SU-8 MP electrodes. All CV measurements were performed using a solution of 30 mM potassium ferricyanide (K
3
Fe(CN)
6
) and 300 mM potassium nitrate (KNO
3
). The potential was swept −0.1 to 0.5 V with a scan rate of 30 mV/s. (f) ECSA of the Si MP electrode and average ECSA of replicated SU-8 MP electrodes.

div.h4: 2.1.2. Micromolding of the SU-8 MP Electrode
div.div:
After obtaining Si MP arrays as a master mold, SU-8 MP arrays were replicated using a PDMS based micromolding process (
Figures
2
d-h and
S1
). To facilitate the intact separation of a PDMS mold from the Si MP arrays, Si MP arrays were coated with Parylene C (diX C, Daisan Kasei Co., Ltd.) (50 nm thick) before being replicated to a PDMS mold. To completely fill in the negative PDMS mold with SU-8, a vacuum degassing process was applied. The SU-8 2010 solution was poured on a PDMS mold containing female MP cavities, and the mold was placed in a vacuum desiccator to remove the trapped air in the MP cavities for 5 times, 30 s each. Then, the solvent contained in the SU-8 solution was evaporated by soft baking on a hot plate followed by removing SU-8 residue on the mold, which was conducted by doctor blading. Afterward, the mold was cured in a UV cross-linker chamber and postexposure baking was conducted on a hot plate at 95 °C for 10 min. SU-8 MP arrays were demolded from the female PDMS mold after hard baking in a vacuum oven at 120 °C for 2 h. Then finally, the Au film as a conducting layer was sputtered, after 4-ATP was coated as an adhesion promotion layer. To confirm the presence of 4-ATP on the SU-8 surface, we performed SEM imaging and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) (
Figure S2
). In order to evaluate how precisely SU-8 MP structures were replicated from the Si MP master mold, the diameter and height of SU-8 MP were measured. The MP of the SU-8 electrode has a 1 μm diameter. The average height of each SU-8 MP (
n
= 3) was 0.92 ± 0.04 μm (
Figure
3
a-ii–iv and 1.65 ± 0.04 μm (
Figure
3
a-ii–iv for A/R of 1 and 1.8 of Si master mold, respectively (
Figure
3
c). The heights of each SU-8 micropillar are 92% and 91.6% compared to each Si master mold, respectively.

div.h4: 2.1.3. Electrochemical Characterization of SU-8 MP Electrode
div.div:
After fabrication, both Si and SU-8 electrodes were electrically connected to the wire with silver paste and covered with epoxy as an insulator. The ECSA of both electrodes were measured by cyclic voltammetry (CV) using a standard redox mediator of K
3
Fe(CN)
6
. An electrolyte solution contained 30 mM of K
3
Fe(CN)
6
as a redox mediator and 300 mM of KNO
3
as a supporting electrolyte for ECSA measurement. A standard three-electrode system with a Pt mesh as a counter electrode and an Ag/AgCl electrode as a reference electrode was used for CV measurement. The sweeping potentials across an anode (both Si and SU-8 MP electrode) and a reference electrode were applied between −0.1 and 0.5 V at a scanning rate of 30 mV/s for CV measurement. To evaluate the effect of MP structures on the enhanced ECSA, flat electrodes were compared to the A/R of 1 and 1.8 of both Si MP electrode (
Figure
3
d) and SU-8 MP electrode (
Figure
3
e). The estimated ECSA and measured peak to peak currents of both Si and SU-8 MP electrodes are shown in
Tables
1
and
2
. The estimated ECSA of the Si MP electrode was similar to the SU-8 MP electrode (
Figure
3
f). In addition, the ECSA of an A/R 1.8 SU-8 MP electrode was 2 times higher than that of a flat electrode. The ECSA of each MP electrode was calculated based on the Randles-Sevcik equation.
(31)
Table 1. Estimated ECSA of Si MP Electrode with Different A/R from Measured Peak to Peak Current in CV
Table 2. Estimated ECSA of SU-8 MP Electrode with Different A/R from Measured Peak to Peak Current in CV

div.h3: 2.2. Electrospraying of TM–Alginate Solution on SU-8 MP Electrode
div.div:
For effective extraction of photosynthetic electrons, it is crucial to maximize the contact area between TMs and a surface of three-dimensional electrode. Therefore, uniformity of deposited TMs on the MP electrode is important to maximize the performance of TM-deposited photoanodes. In this work, electrospraying was employed to achieve uniform coating of a TM–alginate film on an SU-8 MP electrode. The feasibility of electrosprayed TM–alginate film was investigated with a comparison between conventional drop-casting and electrospraying. Thus, the morphology and distribution of both electrosprayed TMs and drop-cast TMs were observed by optical microscopy.
Figure
4
a shows the photograph of drop-cast TMs on an SU-8 MP electrode. The distribution of drop-cast TMs was different between the center (
Figure
4
b) and the edge (
Figure
4
c) of the electrode. As shown in
Figure
4
e–g, however, the electrosprayed TMs were uniformly dispersed regardless of the positions of the electrode (
Figure
4
f,g). To confirm how TMs were filled in the gaps between individual MPs, SEM images were compared between drop-cast and electrosprayed samples (
Figure
4
d,h). As shown in the inset of
Figure
4
d, the cavity was formed between drop-cast TMs and MP arrays. On the other hand, electrosprayed TMs completely filled in the gaps between the MP arrays (
Figure
4
h inset). The thickness of drop-cast TMs from the bottom of the electrode seemed thicker than that of electrosprayed TMs.

div.p: Figure 4. TM coating on SU-8 MP electrode by drop casting or electrospraying. (a) Photograph, (b, c) optical microscope images at two different points from the same sample, (d) SEM images of drop cast sample. (e) Photograph, (f, g) optical microscopy images at two different points from the same sample, and (h) SEM images of drop cast sample. Scale bar in (a,e) is 1 cm. Inset images show cross section views of TM on MP electrode. Scale bar is 1 μm.

div.div:
For uniform deposition of TMs on an SU-8 MP electrode, an electrospraying method was applied to the entire area of a micropillar pattern (1 × 1 cm
2
). As shown in
Figure
5
a, the batch of fabricated SU-8 MP electrodes were placed on the stage of an electrospinning machine. To increase the viscosity of the TM solution for electrospraying, sodium alginate was added to the solution as reported previously.
(17)
TM–alginate solution was electrosprayed on SU-8 MP electrodes through a 23G needle tip connected to syringe pump at a feed rate of 7 μL/min. To fixate TM–alginate film electrosprayed on an SU-8 MP electrode, 50 μL of a calcium chloride (CaCl
2
) solution (50 mM) was gently drop-cast on the TM dispersed SU-8 MP electrode after an electrospraying process. To assess the uniformity of the electrosprayed films of TMs, the average thickness of the film of TMs were estimated at the nine points on SU-8 MP electrodes. Conformally dispersed TMs were visually confirmed by confocal fluorescence microscopy (
Figure
5
b). As shown in
Figure
5
c, the distribution of the film thickness of TMs was estimated from the representative image of confocal fluorescence microscopy. The thickness variation of the TM–alginate film at different points was small, and the average thickness was 8.1 μm.

div.p: Figure 5. (a) Schematic of electrospraying of TM–alginate film on an SU-8 MP electrode. (b) Confocal fluorescence image of electrosprayed TM–alginate film. (c) Thickness distribution of the TM–alginate film from nine different points. (d) SEM image of TMs on a flat electrode at 30° tilted view. SEM images of electrosprayed (e) alginate film and (f) TM–alginate film in 30° tilted view. (g) SEM image of the TM-alg-MP electrode in a cross-sectional view.

div.div:
To verify uniformly electrosprayed TMs on the SU-8 MP electrode, SEM images of the samples were obtained (
Figure
5
d–g). To confirm the intact shape of TMs, TMs were immediately drop-cast and fixed on flat electrode (
Figure
5
d). It was observed that TM vesicles were stacked into grana. A single thylakoid has a disc shape with the diameter of 350 to 500 nm, which is consistent with previous reports.
(17,28)
To confirm the morphology of TMs from the electrosprayed TM–alginate film on an SU-8 MP electrode, both the electrosprayed alginate film and the TM–alginate film were compared (
Figure
5
e,f). As shown in
Figure
5
e, MP arrays were shaded due to the low electrical conductivity of alginate. The vesicles of TMs embedded in an alginate hydrogel film covered over SU-8 MP structures in a 30° tilt view (
Figure
5
f). As shown in the cross-section view of the SEM images, electrosprayed TMs filled in the gaps between the MP arrays of an SU-8 electrode (
Figure
5
g). In addition, the dependency of the TM–alginate film thickness on the electrospraying time was analyzed from the cross-section SEM images (
Figure S3
). The thickness of the TM–alginate film ranged from 0.6 to 5.9 μm on average for electrospraying times of 0.5, 2, 4, and 10 min, respectively (
n
= 50). TM–alginate film thickness is summarized in
Table
3
. TM–alginate films electrosprayed for 4 min were thinner than the height of SU-8 MPs of A/R 1.8.
Table 3. Estimated Thickness of TM–Alginate Film with Electrospraying Times

div.h4: 2.3.1. PE Current from Electrosprayed TM–Alginate Film
div.div:
In order to discriminate PE currents from electrosprayed TMs, no film, alginate film, TM–alginate film deposited electrodes were prepared, and the magnitudes of light-triggered currents generated from each MP photoanode were compared. As the schematic in
Figure
6
a, a three-electrode system was prepared for the PE current measurement. Photoanodes with and without TM film, a Pt mesh, and an Ag/AgCl electrode were connected to a potentiostat as a working, counter, and reference electrode, respectively. A light-triggered current measurement was conducted with a working electrode at 400 mV of a potential against a reference electrode. The whole experiment was performed in a custom-built faraday cage under 10 mW/cm
2
intensity of a halogen lamp. As shown in
Figure
6
b, light-triggered currents were measured at 5 nA/cm
2
from both no film and alginate film cases, while the PE currents were about 90 nA/cm
2
from the TM–alginate film. To confirm whether the PE currents originated from TMs, 3-(3,4-dichlorophenyl)-1,1dimethylurea (DCMU) (D2425, Sigma-Aldrich), a photosynthetic inhibitor, was applied to the electrosprayed TM–alginate film. After adding a 100 μM of DCMU, the light-triggered current decreased to 7 nA/cm
2
from each TM-alg-MP electrode. There was also strong dependency of the magnitude of PE currents on the height of MP electrodes (
Figure
6
c). As the AR of MP electrodes increased from 0 to 1 to 1.8, the PE currents also increased from 47.3 to 73.6 to 104.2 nA/cm
2
.

div.p: Figure 6. PE current measurement with TM-alg-MP electrode. (a) Schematic of light-triggered photosynthetic current measurement with the standard three-electrode system that has TM-alg-MP electrode as an anode, Pt mesh as a counter electrode, and Ag/AgCl as a reference electrode. (b) Confirmation of photosynthetic current originated from TM. (c) Photosynthetic current measured with the different A/R of the TM-alg-MP electrode; TM–alginate electrosprayed in 4 min. (d) Photosynthetic current measured with different electrospraying times from 0.5 to 10 min.

div.h4: 2.3.2. Dependency of PE Currents on Electrospraying Time
div.div:
For the optimal condition of the TM-alg-MP electrode, the electrospraying time was varied from 0.5, 2, 4, and up to 10 min, and their thicknesses (
Figure S3
) and magnitude of PE currents were measured (
Figure
6
d). PE currents were monitored under a 10 mW/cm
2
intensity halogen lamp at 400 mV of applied potential. As predicted, PE currents were higher for MP electrodes than for a flat electrode. Increase of PE currents from MP electrodes are ascribed to their higher ECSA than a flat electrode, as reported previously.
(16)
The highest PE currents were recorded as 104.2 nA/cm
2
from A/R 1.8 electrodes by 4 min of electrospraying. However, when the electrospraying time was 10 min, PE currents began to decrease. When the TM–alginate film becomes too thick, most of the photons are absorbed at locations far from the electrode surface. Without mediators, since only PEs generated near the electrode surface can be collected, most of PEs produced in thick TM-alginate film tend to flow through the usual photosynthetic electron transfer pathways. As shown in
Figure
6
d, the magnitude of PE currents from flat electrodes, which was 10 min electrosprayed, decreased to almost 50% of the 4 min samples. However, in case of MP electrodes, the magnitude of PE currents from 10 min samples slightly decreased to 77.6% and 87% of 4 min samples with AR of 1 and 1.8, respectively. This strongly indicates that the MP structure shortens the PE conduction distance even for thick TM–alginate coating and effectively increase PE collection efficiency.

Long-term PE extraction from TM-alg-MP electrode was demonstrated by PE current measurement up to 14 days (
Figures
7
and
S5
). To prevent dissolution of electrosprayed TMs film on the electrode, a 50 μL of 50 mM CaCl
2
solution was drop-cast on the 4 min-electrosprayed TM-alg-MP electrode for physical cross-linking of the alginate. To confirm whether the cross-linked TM–alginate film was detached from the photoanode, a UV/vis spectrometer was utilized. Cross-linked samples for 1 min and for 24 h samples were immersed PBS solution for 30 min, then each sample was removed from the solution. The absorbance peak was measured at 645 nm (
Chl b
) and 663 nm (
Chl a
) from the solution immersed in cross-linked TM-alginate for 1 min (
Figure S4a
). No peak was measured from the 24 h cross-linked samples (
Figure S4b
). This indicates that the TM–alginate film was firmly attached to the electrode without dismantling of the film. After TM–alginate cross-linked for 24 h, around 95 nA/cm
2
of PE current were maintained for 14 days without significant decrease after first measurement. All PE currents were monitored under 10 mW/cm
2
and 400 mV of bias potential applied condition.

div.p:
Figure 7. Long-term sustainable PE currents from TM-alg-MP electrode with A/R 1.8 for 14 days. PE currents were monitored from 24 h after cross-linked as a 1
st
measurement (black line), 1 day (dark yellow line), 4 days (green line), 10 days (red line), and 14 days (dark blue line) after 1
st
measurement.

div.div:
To assess the scalability of TM-alg-MP electrodes, total 10 of TM-alg-MP electrodes were serially connected (
Figure
8
a). The measured PE currents were 0.77, 1.2, and 1.8 μA for the TM-alg-MP electrode assembly with flat, A/R 1, and, A/R 1.8, respectively (
Figure
8
b). The PE currents increased with larger contact area in accordance with the higher A/R between TMs and the electrode, as expected. As depicted in
Figure
8
c, as the light intensity was varied from 10 to 68 mW/cm
2
, PE currents from TM-alg-MP electrode (A/R 1.8) assembly increased from 1.8 to 3.2 μA.

div.p:
Figure 8. Scalable photosynthetic currents from the TM-alg-MP electrode assembly. (a) Photograph of the photosynthetic current measurement setup. (b) Confirmation of superposition effect of photosynthetic currents on the TM-alg-MP electrode assembly with different A/R. (c) Photosynthetic currents from the TM-alg-MP electrode (A/R 1.8) assembly with different illumination intensities from 10 to 68 mW/cm
2
.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The design of the SU-8 MP electrode was based on the dimension of thylakoid vesicles extracted from spinach leaves. Each vesicle of thylakoid was 350–500 nm in size (
Figure
5
d), as reported in previous works.
(17,28)
We designed a three-dimensional MP structured electrode with a high surface area to volume ratio. To accommodate TM on an MP electrode with a maximum direct contact area, the diameter of and spacing between each MP was determined to be 1 μm.

There have been reports about various fabrication methods of Si micro/nano wires; vapor–liquid–solid (VLS) as a bottom-up method or deep reactive ion etching (DRIE) as a top-down method were mainly investigated.
(32,33)
However, the orientation control of Si micro/nano wires is difficult in the VLS-growth method,
(34)
and the DRIE process requires costly equipment like a vacuum chamber and RF generators, etc.
(35)
Recently, MACE has widely been used in various applications due to its low-cost, simplicity, robustness, and availability under atmospheric pressure and room temperature.
(36−38)
Despite all the advantages in MACE, such a process based on wet etching was difficult to repeatedly achieve the same dimensions of the electrode and its cost is not inexpensive.
(39,40)
To repeatably fabricate the identical dimensions of the electrode but with an inexpensive price is crucial for the engineering of a photoanode. SU-8 as a UV curable material is widely utilized for replication of the silicon structure because of its easy processing and suitable mechanical properties.
(41)
Despite the advantages of SU-8, it is rather difficult to deposit a conductive layer on SU-8 structures due to the poor adhesion between SU-8 and most metals. In this work, a 4-ATP as an adhesion layer was used to deposit an Au layer as a conducting layer on SU-8 MP arrays. As shown in
Figure
3
, the replication accuracy and electrical functionality of the SU-8 MP electrode was confirmed by comparison of the Si MP electrode to the master mold.

Although there have been many reports of high PE current densities, most of them were measured using extremely small electrodes. For instance, a 1 μL TM solution was drop-cast on a surface of 0.126 cm
2
AuNP modified screen-printed Au electrode (3.2 μg of chlorophyll contents)
(18)
or a 1.5 μL TM solution was dropped on the 0.0731 cm
2
of a graphite rod modified with CNTs (3.2 mg·chl/ml).
(19)
A 20 μL TM solution was deposited on a conducting polymer decorated carbon paper electrode (0.07 mg·chl/ml).
(20)
Despite the promising results, scalable fabrication of any device is less feasible with the approaches based on drop casting of TM composites on electrodes. In our work, a TM–alginate solution was electrosprayed uniformly on electrodes to maximize the interaction between TM and MP electrodes. As shown in
Figure
5
, the feasibility of electrospraying over the SU-8 MP electrode was investigated in comparison with drop-casting. Drop-cast TMs showed uneven thickness and nonuniformity due to the coffee stain effect. More seriously, drop-cast TMs were not able to fill the gaps between each MP. Meanwhile, electrosprayed TMs fully filled the space between and showed uniform distribution between each MP in the entire area of the electrode.

An artificial redox-mediator was usually exploited to many TM-based PBEC energy harvesting works. Although mediators facilitate electron transfer to an anode, they may cause a voltage loss in PBEC cells and limited long-term stability due to their vulnerability to light and temperature.
(42)
Regarding other approaches to enhance PE extraction without using the mediators, TM was directly immobilized on the surface of an electrode via linker molecules, or mixed with nanomaterials to create electrical pathways to an electrode. TM was immobilized on MWCNTs by 1-pyrenebutanoic acid succinimidyl ester (PBSE)
(21)
or carboxyphenyl groups on a glassy carbon electrode,
(22)
oligo-electrolytes were used to conjugate with an electrode,
(23)
and osmium redox polymer was exploited to be electrically wired between the TM and an electrode.
(18,23,24)
The composite films of TM and GO/rGO were investigated,
(25)
or TM and MWCNTs were mixed to improve the electrochemical junction.
(19,21,26)

Such enhanced electron transfer, however, with linker molecules or conductive nanomaterials is effective only for a monolayer or an extremely thin layer of TMs. Ideally, to increase the PE current density, PE extraction from a thick TM film is highly desirable and is critical to form short PE conduction paths from a thick TM film to an electrode. As shown in
Figure
5
g, when the size of the individual TMs ranges from 350 to 500 nm and the TM film thickness is a couple of micrometers, PE transfer to the bottom electrode occurs only to the TMs that directly contact or are linked via linker molecules to the electrode. With three-dimensional MP electrodes in this study, TMs that are far away from the bottom electrode can directly contact or are much closer to the side walls of MP electrodes, leading to enhanced PE collection efficiency. In our work, a 47.3 nA/cm
2
of PE current density was monitored from a flat electrode, while the PE current density from MP electrode with AR of 1.8 increased to 104.2 nA/cm
2
(
Figure
6
c).

For the practical application of PE harvesting, the guarantee of long-term operation and the stability of a PBEC system needs to be ensured. For examples, the photosynthetic energy harvesting from algal cells was successfully demonstrated for 7 days.
(10,11)
In the electron transfer process of photosynthesis, reactive oxygen species (ROS) are produced and damage the isolated photosynthetic apparatuses such as PS I and PS II or TMs.
(43−45)
Thus, PBECs using isolated TMs are vulnerable to ROS damage and typically show rapid degeneration of their performance. To reduce ROS damage to the photosynthesis of isolated TMs, an ROS scavenging enzyme, catalase, was utilized and demonstrated effective reduction of ROS damage.
(42,46)
However, as shown in
Figure
7
, without using the catalase in this study, PE harvesting with TM-alg-MP electrodes was sustained for 14 days. Polysaccharides including alginate are known to reduce the damaging effect of ROS, and the protection mechanisms of alginate against ROS have been investigated.
(47−49)
As a potential mechanism, polysaccharides are likely to prevent drying of cells and organisms, resulting in the reduction of ROS accumulation.

During the long-term monitoring, the transient current behavior was maintained during 14 days only in the case of the A/R 1.8 TM-alg-MP electrode (
Figure
7
). However, in case of a flat electrode, the transient behavior diminished gradually after 10 days (
Figure S5
). Sharp PE current peaks occur upon illumination, possibly due to the rapid decrease of H
+
ions in the vicinity of TMs. During photosynthesis, H
+
ions are consumed by photosynthetic apparatuses in the stroma (outside) of the TMs, while H
+
ions are produced in the TM lumen by water splitting. It is reported that a Au electrode can form an oxide layer (Au
2
O
3
) and responds to the change of H
+
.
(50)
Reduction of H
+
ions in the medium can cause the release of H
+
ions from the Au oxide layer, resulting in temporary anodic currents. This phenomenon is more clearly observed in this study, since TMs form direct contacts with the surface of the Au electrode. However, with regard to the TM–alginate mixture on a flat electrode, the TM–alginate mixture is likely to swell and become detached from the electrode surface. This detachment mitigates the influence of H
+
change to the PE currents and reduces the generation of the peak PE currents upon illumination. Alternatively, the TM–alginate mixture on an MP electrode is stably anchored betweenmicropillar structures and maintains direct contact with the Au oxide surface.

Most research works regarding TM decorated biophotoanodes were focused on how to increase the efficiency of PE extraction. In particular, the formation of electrical pathways between TMs and an anode was investigated mainly using nanomaterials such as CNTs
(21,26)
and GO,
(25,28)
and osmium redox polymer.
(19,23)
In this work, we hypothesized that the use of MP electrodes not only increased the electrode surface area, but also provided electrical pathways with TMs that were not in direct contact with main electrodes. This was clearly shown in
Figures
6
and
8
, where the magnitude of the PE current was enhanced in accordance with the A/R of MP electrodes, and the PE current of the TM-alg-MP electrode assembly was superposed from each single photoanode. Compared to the electrodes with A/R = 0 (flat electrodes), without using any nanomaterial or mediator molecule, MPs with higher A/R values produced larger PE currents. This suggests that the use of MP electrodes together with nanomaterials for electrical networks can further enhance the PE extraction efficiency without any mediator.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div: We fabricated TM-electrosprayed SU-8 MP electrodes for scalable and long-term sustainable photosynthetic energy harvesting. SU-8 MP electrodes with an optimum design for maximized direct contact with TMs were successfully replicated from Si MP arrays. A mixture of TM–alginate was uniformly electrosprayed on SU-8 MP electrodes to conformally coat the surface of each MP electrode. Larger PE currents were measured from MP electrodes with higher A/R, indicating enhanced direct contact between TMs and 3D MP electrodes. Serial connection of multiple TM-electrosprayed SU-8 MP electrodes was also demonstrated and PE currents of up to ∼3.2 μA were achieved without the aid of any mediator.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Phosphate buffer saline (PBS) tablet (P4471, Sigma-Aldrich), saccharose (7501–4405, Daejung chemicals and metals Co., Ltd.), and magnesium chloride (MgCl
2
·6H
2
O) (DB5581, Duksan Highchem Corp.) were used as a buffer solution for isolating TMs from spinach and photocurrent measurement. A p-type Si wafer (resistivity >1 Ω·cm, ⟨100⟩ orientation) used as a substrate for Si MP arrays, was purchased from LG Siltron Inc. Hydrofluoric acid (HF) (HDC0-00101, Duksan Highchem Corp.) and hydrogen peroxide (H
2
O
2
) (HDE0-18220, Duksan Highchem Corp.) were used as the etchant compound for metal-assisted chemical etching (MAC-Etching). A gold etchant (standard, 651818) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich for removal of the catalyst metal. Poly(dimethylsiloxane) (PDMS) (Sylgard 184, Dow Corning Corp.) and SU-8 negative photoresist (SU-8 2010, MicroChem Corp.) were used for the micromolding process. 4-Aminothiophenol (4-ATP, 422967) as an adhesion layer between Au and SU-8 MP arrays, was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Ammonium acetate (NH
4
CH
3
CO
2
) (1052-4405, Daejung Chemicals and Metals Co., Ltd.), ethanol (4023-4104, Daejung Chemicals and Metals Co., Ltd.), sodium alginate (7528-1405, Daejung Chemicals and Metals Co., Ltd.) were used for the electrospraying solution. Calcium chloride (CaCl
2
) (2507-1400) was purchased from Daejung Chemicals and Metals Co., Ltd. as a cross-linking agent. Potassium ferricyanide (K
3
Fe(CN)
6
) (702587, Sigma-Aldrich) and potassium nitrate (KNO
3
) (P8394, Sigma-Aldrich) were used as a redox mediator to confirm the electrochemical properties of the fabricated SU-8 MP electrode. An Ag/AgCl electrode (E200) as a reference electrode was purchased from Warner Instruments and a platinum mesh electrode (002250) was purchased from ALS Co., Ltd. as a counter electrode in all electrochemical measurements. A silver paste (Elcoat P-100, Cans) was used to electrically connect the Au layer with wire. An epoxy glue (EP-30, AXIA) as an insulating layer was covered over the silver paste. 25% (v/v) glutaraldehyde solution (G5882, Sigma-Aldrich) and 4% (v/v) osmium tetraoxide solution (75632, Sigma-Aldrich) were used for fixation and imaging of the TMs. Aqueous solutions for all experiments were exploited to deionized water (18.3MΩ·cm
–1
) distilled from a water purification system (Pure Power I
+
, Human Corporation Co., Ltd., Korea).

SU-8 MP electrode was fabricated through consecutive processes of photolithography, MACE, and micro molding. To obtain a patterned Au film on Si substrate as MACE catalyst. A photoresist (PR) (TDUR-P902, Tokyo OHKA Kogyo Co., Ltd.) was coated on Si wafer by a spin coater. A PR template was patterned by photolithography using the KrF stepper (PAS5500, ASML). Then, 2 and 20 nm thick layers of Ti and Au were deposited by an E-beam evaporator (UEE, Ultech Co., Ltd.) at 0.1 nm/sec rate followed by lift-off. A patterned Si wafer with Au hexagonal lattice catalyst was diced in 2 × 1 cm
2
pieces by dicing saw (DAD3350, DISCO). To obtain Si MP arrays, a Au patterned Si substrate was immersed and anisotropically etched in solution of HF and H
2
O
2
at 5:1 of mixing ratio. SU-8 MP electrode was replicated from Si MP arrays as a master mold. PDMS mold was replicated from a Si master mold. SU-8 2010 solution was filled in the PDMS mold followed by soft baking at 95 °C on hot plate (MSH-20D, Daihan Scientific Co., Ltd.) for 10 min. SU-8 MP arrays was demolded from PDMS mold after UV irradiation using UV cross-linker (BIO-LINK BLX, Vilber Lourmat) at 2 mW/cm
2
of intensity for 15 min. After demolding SU-8 MP arrays, post exposure baking was conducted and followed by hard baking at 120 °C in vacuum oven for 2 h. To deposit an adhesion layer, SU-8 MP arrays was immersed in 10 mM of 4-ATP ethanol solution during overnight and dried with nitrile gun. Then, 100 nm thick films of Au as an anode layer was deposited using magnetron sputter (KOVA, Repubilc of Korea). After each step of fabrication, the geometry of each sample was observed by field effect scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) (JSM-7001F, JEOL, Ltd.)

div.h3: 5.4. TM–Alginate Film Electrospraying Setup and Conditions
div.div:
The isolated TMs concentration was estimated by measuring the absorbance of chlorophyll using UV–vis spectrometer (V-650, JASCO Corporation) and calculating using the conversion equation of the previous work.
(51)
The chlorophyll concentration of isolated TMs was determined as 1.5 to 4 mg·chl/ml, then adjusted in 1 mg·chl/ml for electrospraying solution. TMs contained electrospraying solution parameters and setup was prepared as previous studies.
(17)
TM contained electrospraying solution was prepared with 3 mM ammonium acetate, 10% (v/v) ethanol, and 0.3% (w/v) sodium alginate. Ammonium acetate was added for enhancement of solution conductivity, ethanol was added to decrease the surface tension of solution, and sodium alginate was used as a viscosity modifier for stable electrospraying process. TMs were electrosprayed onto the SU-8 MP electrode using a commercial electrospinning system (ESR200RD, Nano NC Inc., Seoul, Republic of Korea). While electrospraying, a 6.4 kV of bias voltage was applied to the solution, and the substrate was grounded. The substrate placed SU-8 MP electrode moved at a speed of 4000 mm/min in both X and Y directions. TM–alginate solution electrosprayed through the needle tip, which maintained a distance of 12 mm from the substrate, connected to syringe pump (fusion 200, Chemyx Inc., U.S.A.). Preprogrammed each step distance in the
Y
direction was maintained as 0.1 mm. The solution was electrosprayed via a 23 G needle tip (inner diameter = 337 μm).

The morphology of the TMs on the SU-8 MP electrode was analyzed using both SEM and confocal fluorescence microscope (LSM 880, Carl Zeiss). In order to observe the morphology of TMs with FE-SEM, fixation of extracted TMs and electrosprayed TMs was conducted. The extracted TMs were drop-cast on flat Au electrode and dried. TMs were fixed in 3% (v/v) glutaraldehyde with 10 mM PBS solution (pH7.4) for 2 h followed by rinsing with the PBS solution (pH7.4) for 10 min three times. Then, TMs was postfixed in 2% (v/v) Osmium tetraoxide with the PBS solution for 4 h. After TM fixation, intracellular fluid was gradually exchanged by titration process. Both drop-cast and electrosprayed TMs were consecutively soaked in 30, 50, 70, 80, 90, 95% aqueous ethanol solution, and TMs were soaked 3 times in 100% ethanol. Afterward, TM fixed samples were dried overnight in a vacuum desiccator for evaporation of ethanol before imaging with FE-SEM. All TMs fixation processes were conducted at room temperature.

For all electrochemical measurments, a standard three electrode configuration connected to a potentiostat (CompactStat, Ivium Technologies) was set in a custom-built faraday cage. The three-electrode system was composed of a SU-8 MP electrode as an anode, a Pt mesh electrode as a counter electrode, and an Ag/AgCl electrode as a reference electrode. In the CV analysis of a SU-8 MP electrode, −0.1 V to 0.5 V of scan range was set against the reference electrode, and the scan rate was set at 30 mV/s. A redox mediator solution was prepared to contain 30 mM of K
3
Fe(CN)
6
, while 300 mM of KNO
3
performed as a supporting electrolyte. For measuring PE current from TM, a chronoamperometry method was performed. Bias potentials of 0.4 V were applied to TM-alginate electrosprayed SU-8 MP photoanode against the Ag/AgCl electrode. A PBS without any mediator was used as an electrolyte for direct extraction of PEs. The TM–alginate electrosprayed photoanode was illuminated with a 100 W halogen lamp (LG-PS2, Olympus), and light intensity was set at 10 mW/cm
2
for all PE current measurement unless it was stated otherwise.

Solar energy conversion: From natural to artificial photosynthesis
El-Khouly, Mohamed E.; El-Mohsnawy, Eithar; Fukuzumi, Shunichi
Journal of Photochemistry and Photobiology, C: Photochemistry Reviews
(
2017
),

(

36-83

; ISSN:
1389-5567
.
(
Elsevier B.V.
)
Solar energy has a great potential as a clean, cheap, renewable and sustainable energy source, but it must be captured and transformed into useful forms of energy as plants do. An esp. attractive approach is to store solar energy in the form of chem. bonds as performed in natural photosynthesis. Therefore, there is a challenge in the last decades to construct semi-artificial and artificial photosynthetic systems, which are able to efficiently capture and convert solar energy and then store it in the form of chem. bonds of solar fuels such as hydrogen or hydrogen peroxide, while at the time producing oxygen from water. Here, we review the mol. level details of the natural photosynthesis, particularly the mechanism of light dependent reactions in oxygen evolving organisms, absorption efficiency of solar energy and direct energy prodn. We then demonstrate the concept and examples of the semi-artificial photosynthesis in vitro. Finally we demonstrate the artificial photosynthesis, which is composed of light harvesting and charge-sepn. units together with catalytic units of water oxidn. and redn. as well as CO2 redn. The reported photosynthetic mol. and supramol. systems have been designed and examd. in order to mimic functions of the antenna-reaction center of the natural process. The relations between structures and photochem. behaviors of these artificial photosynthetic systems are discussed in relation to the rates and efficiencies of charge-sepn. and charge-recombination processes by utilizing the laser flash photolysis technique, as well as other complementary techniques. Finally the photocatalytic prodn. of hydrogen peroxide as a more promising solar fuel is discussed in relation with the natural photosynthesis, which also produces hydrogen peroxide in addn. to NADPH.

The widely assumed correspondence between fluorescence and photochem. in photosynthetic systems has recently been challenged by observations on the triplet state of bacteriochlorophyll in reaction centers of R. spheroides. A precise detn. of the quantum efficiency of bacteriochlorophyll photooxidn. in reaction centers at room temp. was made. A quantum efficiency of 1.02 ± 0.04 was found in contrast to a value of ∼0.7 predicted from the variations in fluorescence yield.

Photosynthetic microbial fuel cells (PMFCs) are an emerging technol. for renewable solar energy conversion. Major efforts have been made to explore the electrogenic activity of cyanobacteria, mostly using practically unsustainable reagents. Here we report on photocurrent generation (≈8.64 μA cm-2) from cyanobacteria immobilized on electrodes modified with an efficient electron mediator, an Os2+/3+ redox polymer. Upon addn. of ferricyanide to the electrolyte, cyanobacteria generate the max. c.d. of ≈48.2 μA cm-2.

Microliter-scale photosynthetic microbial fuel cells (micro-PMFC) can be the most suitable power source for unattended environmental sensors because the technique can continuously generate electricity from microbial photosynthesis and respiration through day-night cycles, offering a clean and renewable power source with self-sustaining potential. However, the promise of this technol. has not been translated into practical applications because of its relatively low performance. By creating an innovative supercapacitive micro-PMFC device with maximized bacterial photoelectrochem. activities in a well-controlled, tightly enclosed micro-chamber, this work established innovative strategies to revolutionize micro-PMFC performance to attain stable high power and c.d. (38 μW/cm2 and 120 μA/cm2) that then potentially provides a practical and sustainable power supply for the environmental sensing applications. The proposed technique is based on a 3-D double-functional bio-anode concurrently exhibiting bio-electrocatalytic energy harvesting and charge storing. It offers the high-energy harvesting functionality of micro-PMFCs with the high-power operation of an internal supercapacitor for charging and discharging. The performance of the supercapacitive micro-PMFC improved significantly through miniaturizing innovative device architectures and connecting multiple miniature devices in series.

There are many sources of bioenergy that are generated by photosynthetic processes, for example, lipids, alcs., H, and polysaccharides. However only a small fraction of solar energy absorbed by photosynthetic organisms is converted to a form of energy that can be readily exploited. To more efficiently use the solar energy harvested by photosynthetic organisms, the authors evaluated the feasibility of generating bio-electricity by directly extg. electrons from the photosynthetic electron transport chain before they are used to fix CO2 into sugars and polysaccharides. From a living algal cell, Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, photosynthetic electrons (1.2 pA at 6000 mA/m2) were directly extd. without a mediating electron carrier by inserting a nanoelectrode into the algal chloroplast and applying an overvoltage. This result may represent an initial step in generating high-efficiency bio-electricity by directly harvesting high energy photosynthetic electrons.

An electrochem. active nanowire system is fabricated using wet-tapped nanosphere lithog. and a single photolithog. step. The patterned nanowire/nanoelectrode is inserted into live algal cells, enabling the potential harvesting of photosynthetic electrons from multiple cells simultaneously. Light-dependent extn. of electrons from cells is obsd.; these electrons are derived from the photosynthetic electron transport chain based on a light intensity-dependence of the reaction coupled with the finding that electron extn. is inhibited in the presence of DCMU (3-(3,4-dichlorophenyl)-1,1-dimethylurea), a reagent that specifically blocks electron flow out of photosystem II. Insertion of nanoelectrodes into multiple algal cells is achieved, and sequential insertion of cells with the nanoelectrode, followed by subsequent removal of the electrode, yields a corresponding increase and then decrease in light-driven currents. Controlling the intensity of the illumination avoids nearly all photodamage and enables direct extn. of more photosynthetic electrons from multiple cells in parallel, which is sustained for an extended period of time.

Harvesting photosynthetic electrons (PEs) from plant or algal cells can be a highly efficient and environmentally friendly way of generating renewable energy. Recent work on nanoelectrode insertion into algal cells has demonstrated the possibility to directly ext. PEs from living algal cells with high efficiencies. However, the instability of the inserted cells limits the practicality of this technol. Here, the impact of nanoelectrode insertion on intracellular extn. of PEs is characterized with the goal of stabilizing algal cells after nanoelectrode insertion. Using nanoelectrodes <500 nm in diam., algal cells remained stable for over one week after insertion and continued to provide PEs through direct extn. by the inserted nanoelectrodes. After nanoelectrode insertion, a photosynthetic c.d. of 6 mA·cm-2, which is several fold higher than the current densities attained using approaches based on isolated thylakoid membranes or photosystem I complexes, was obsd. in the dark and during illumination at various light intensities. Direct extn. of photosynthetic electrons from the whole photosynthetic cells such as plant cells or algal cells can be highly efficient and sustainable compared to other approaches based on isolated photosynthetic app. such as photosystems I, II, and thylakoid membranes. However, insertion of nanoelectrodes (NEs) into individual cells are time-consuming and unsuitable for scale-up processes. We propose simple and efficient insertion of massively-populated NEs into cell films in which algal cells are densely packed in a monolayer. After stacking the cell film over an NE array, gentle pressing of the stack allows a large no. of NEs to be inserted into the cells in the cell film. The NE array was fabricated by metal-assisted chem. etching (MAC-etching) followed by addnl. steps of wet oxidn. and oxide etching. The cell film was prepd. by mixing highly concd. algal cells with alginate hydrogel. Photosynthetic currents of up to 106 nA/cm2 was achieved without aid of mediators, and the photosynthetic function was maintained for 6 days after NE array insertion into algal cells.

Plants and some types of bacteria demonstrate an elegant means to capitalize on the superabundance of solar energy - photosynthesis. A biomimetic photonic energy conversion system was devised that uses the photoactive protein complex Photosystem I, immobilized on the surface of nanoporous Au leaf (NPGL) electrodes, to drive a photoinduced elec. current through an electrochem. cell. The intent of this study is to further the understanding of how the useful functionality of these naturally mass-produced, biol. light-harvesting complexes can be integrated with non-biol. materials. The protein complexes retain their photonic energy conversion functionality after attachment to the nanoporous electrode surface and, further, that the addnl. PSI/electrode interfacial area provided by the NPGL allows for an increase in PSI-mediated electron transfer with respect to an analogous 2-dimensional system if the pores are sufficiently enlarged by de-alloying. This increase of interfacial area is pertinent for other applications involving electron transfer between phases; thus, the authors also report on the accessible and scalable method by which the NPGL electrode films used in this study are fabricated and attached to glass and Au/Si supports, and demonstrate their adaptability by modification with various self-assembled monolayers. The magnitude of the PSI-catalyzed photocurrents provided by the NPGL electrode films depends on the intensity of the light used to irradiate the electrodes.

The combination of advanced materials and defined surface design with complex proteins from natural photosynthesis is currently one of the major topics in the development of biohybrid systems and biophotovoltaic devices. In this study transparent mesoporous indium tin oxide (μITO) electrodes have been used in combination with the trimeric supercomplex photosystem I (PSI) from Thermosynechococcus elongatus and the small redox protein cytochrome c (cyt c) from horse heart to fabricate advanced and efficient photobiocathodes. The prepn. of the μITO via spin coating allows easy scalability and ensures a defined increase in the electrochem. active surface area with accessibility for both proteins. Using these 3D electrodes up to 40 μm thickness, the immobilization of cyt c and PSI with full monolayer coverage and their elec. communication to the electrode can be achieved. Significant improvement can be made when the heterogeneous electron transfer rate const. of cyt c with the electrode is increased by an appropriate surface treatment. The photocurrent follows linearly the thickness of the μITO and current densities of up to 150 μA/cm2 can be obtained without indications of a limitation. The internal quantum efficiency is detd. to be 39% which demonstrates that the wiring of PSI via cyt c can be advantageously used in a system with high protein loading and efficient electron pathways inside 3D transparent conducting oxides.

A benchmark Photosystem II (PSII)-electrode system that combines the efficient wiring afforded by redox-active polymers with the high loading provided by hierarchically-structured inverse opal indium tin oxide (IO-ITO) electrodes was reported. Compared to flat electrodes, the hierarchical IO-ITO electrodes enabled up to an approx. 50-fold increase in the immobilization of an Os complex-modified and a phenothiazine-modified polymer. When the Os complex-modified polymer is co-adsorbed with PSII on the hierarchical electrodes, photocurrent densities of up to ∼410μA cm-2 at 0.5 V vs. SHE were obsd. in the absence of diffusional mediators, demonstrating a substantially improved wiring of PSII to the IO-ITO electrode with the redox polymer. The high photocurrent d. allowed for the quantification of O2 evolution, and a Faradaic efficiency of 85 ± 9% was measured. As such, we have demonstrated a high performing and fully integrated host-guest system with excellent electronic wiring and loading capacity. This assembly strategy may form the basis of all-integrated electrode designs for a wide range of biol. and synthetic catalysts.

Semiartificial photosynthesis integrates photosynthetic enzymes with artificial electronics, which is an emerging approach to reroute the natural photoelectrogenetic pathways for sustainable fuel and chem. synthesis. However, the reduced catalytic activity of enzymes in bioelectrodes limits the overall performance and further applications in fuel prodn. Here, we show new insights into factors that affect the photoelectrogenesis in a model system consisting of photosystem II and three-dimensional indium tin oxide and graphene electrodes. Confocal fluorescence microscopy and in situ surface-sensitive IR spectroscopy are employed to probe the enzyme distribution and penetration within electrode scaffolds of different structures, which is further correlated with protein film-photoelectrochem. to establish relationships between the electrode architecture and enzyme activity. We find that the hierarchical structure of electrodes mainly influences the protein loading but not the enzyme activity. Photoactivity is more limited by light intensity and electronic communication at the biointerface. This study provides guidelines for maximizing the performance of semiartificial photosynthesis and also presents a set of methodologies to probe the photoactive biofilms in three-dimensional electrodes.

For extn. of photosynthetic electrons (PEs) from plant cells and algal cells, there have been many approaches using living algal cells or isolated photosynthetic app. such as photosystem II, photosystem I, and thylakoid membranes (TMs). Among these, bio-photoanodes coated with TMs demonstrated stable performance and the possibility for their practical applications. When a TM photoanode is prepd., TMs are deposited on the surface of a metal electrode. However, since the thickness of TM films dets. the light absorption and electron transfer processes, the performance of a TM bio-photoanode is significantly affected by the TM film quality. Thus, electrospraying was employed to deposit TMs with enhanced control of the thickness and uniformity of TM coating on metal electrodes. In particular, the authors studied how both the quality of TM films and the magnitude of PE currents were influenced by electrospraying time, substrate motion, soln. feed rates, TM concn., and addn. of graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets. Finally, to assess the feasibility of TM electrospraying as a scalable fabrication method, TMs were electrosprayed on 5 × 5 cm2 size films of In Sn oxide (ITO)-coated polyethylene naphthalate (PEN) (ITO-PEN). The coating uniformity was assessed by measuring PE currents from different locations of the TM-deposited ITO-PEN films.

The authors report on the increase in photocurrent obtained by using thylakoid membranes wired with an Os redox polymer (OsRP) immobilized onto screen-printed C and Au electrodes (SPCEs and SPAuEs), modified with Au microparticles (AuMPs) and Au nanoparticles (AuNPs). Both AuMPs and AuNPs were electrodeposited by using the same electrodeposition method to study the influence of different electrode surface morphologies, AuMPs and AuNPs, on the photocurrent generated when illuminated ΔΔΔ with light with an intensity equiv. to that of sunlight (400 W m-2). AuMPs/SPCEs showed the highest c.d. (62.5 μA cm-2) upon illumination probably due to a higher capacitive current directly related to the enhanced electroactive area (AEA) and roughness factor (ρ). Finally, the so modified electrodes AuMPs/SPCE and AuNPs/SPAuE were characterized by using SEM showing a different surface morphol., resulting in a higher surface roughness for AuMPs/SPCE compared to AuNPs/SPAuE therefore an intimate interaction between the large thylakoid membrane and the AuNPs. A high photocurrent d. of 62.5 μA cm-2 was generated at a light intensity of 400 W m-2.

A combination of photosynthetic biocatalysts with high surface area conductive materials mediated by an Os-complex modified redox polymer (OsRP) holds promising features for the development of sustainable green systems for solar energy conversion. The authors performed a comparative study of two types of C nanotubes (CNTs) synthesized by pyrolysis of polymeric precursors. Both CNTs were of similar morphol., but had a different surface C/O ratio. The CNTs were used as a support for immobilization of thylakoid membranes, electrochem. wired through the OsRP. The photobioanodes based on the CNTs with a higher C/O ratio exhibit a higher max. photocurrent d. of 97.1 ± 8.3μA cm-2 at a light intensity of 400 W m-2 with reduced charge transfer resistance, but had lower operational stability. The authors' results demonstrate the significance of studying of electrochem. communication between the photosynthetic component, the redox mediator and the support nanomaterial and may offer new opportunities for designing and optimization of mediated bioelectrochem. systems.

The resulting thylakoid-carbon nanotube composites showed high photo-electrochem. activity under illumination. Multiple membrane proteins have been obsd. to participate in direct electron transfer with the electrode, resulting in the generation of photocurrents, the first of its kind reported for natural photosynthetic systems. Upon inclusion of a mediator, the photo-activity was enhanced. The major contributor to the photocurrent was the light-induced water oxidn. reaction at the photosystem II complex. The thylakoid-MWNT composite electrode yielded a max. c.d. of 68 μA cm-2 and a steady state c.d. of 38 μA cm-2, which are two orders of magnitude larger than previously reported for similar systems. The high electrochem. activity of the thylakoid-MWNT composites has significant implications for both photosynthetic energy conversion and photofuel prodn. applications. A fuel cell type photosynthetic electrochem. cell developed using a thylakoid-MWNT composite anode and laccase cathode produced a max. power d. of 5.3 μW cm-2, comparable to that of enzymic fuel cells. The carbon based nanostructured electrode has the potential to serve as an excellent immobilization support for photosynthetic electrochem. based on the mol. tethering approach as demonstrated in this work.

Light reactions of photosynthesis that take place in thylakoid membranes found in plants or cyanobacteria are among the most effective ways of utilizing light. Unlike most researches that use photosystem I or photosystem II as conversion units for converting light to electricity, we have developed a simple method in which the thylakoid monolayer was covalently immobilized on the glassy carbon electrode surface. The activity of isolated thylakoid membrane was confirmed by measuring evolving oxygen under illumination. Glassy carbon surfaces were first modified with partial or full monolayers of carboxyphenyl groups by reductive C-C coupling using 4-aminobenzoic acid and aniline and then thylakoid membrane was bioconjugated through the peptide bond between amine residues of thylakoid and carboxyl groups on the surface. Surface properties of modified surfaces were characterized by cyclic voltammetry, contact angle measurements, and electrochem. impedance spectroscopy. Photocurrent of 230 nA cm- 2 was obsd. when the thylakoid monolayer was formed on the mixed monolayer of 4-carboxylpheny and benzene at applied potential of 0.4 V vs. Ag/AgCl. A small photocurrent resulted when the 4-carboxyphenyl full monolayer was used. This work shows the possibility of solar energy conversion by directly employing the whole thylakoid membrane through simple surface modification.

Harvesting the energy generated by photosynthetic organisms through light-dependent reactions is a significant step toward a sustainable future energy supply. Thylakoid membranes are the site of photosynthesis, and thus particularly suited for developing photo-bioelectrochem. cells. Novel electrode materials and geometries could potentially improve the efficiency of energy harvesting using thylakoid membranes. For com. applications, electrodes with large surface areas are needed. Photolithog. patterning of a photoresist, followed by pyrolysis, is a flexible and fast approach for the fabrication of C electrodes with tailored properties. Electrode chips consisting of patterned C supported on quartz were designed and fabricated. The patterned electrode area is 1 cm2, and the measurement chamber footprint is 0.5 cm2, 1 order of magnitude larger than previously tested electrodes for thylakoid membrane immobilization. The use of a transparent substrate allows back-side illumination, protecting the bioelectrochem. system from the environment and vice versa. Two different mediators, monomeric ([Ru(NH3)6]3+) and polymeric ([Os(2,2'-bipyridine)2-poly(N-vinylimidazole)10Cl]+/2+), are used for evaluating photocurrent generation from thylakoid membranes with different electrode geometries. Current densities up to 71 μA cm-2 are measured upon illumination through the transparent electrode chip with solar simulated irradiance (1000 W m-2).

The investigation of natural photosynthetic components integrated electrodes for the construction of photoelectrochem. cells has attracted more and more attention. In this research, thylakoid membrane was integrated with graphene materials for the construction of photoelectrochem. cells and photocurrent of mediated electron transfer was investigated. The functional groups and structural support of graphene oxide could increase local mediator concn. and accelerate diffusional mass transport, thus enhancing the photocurrent d.

A photo-driven bioanode was constructed using the thylakoid membrane from spinach, carbon nanotubes, and an artificial mediator. By considering a linear free-energy relationship in the electron transfer from the thylakoid membrane to the mediators, and the oxygen resistance of the reduced mediators, 1,2-naphthoquinone was selected as the most suitable mediator for the photo-driven bioanode. Water-dispersed multi-walled carbon nanotubes served as scaffolds to hold the thylakoid membrane on a porous electrode. The constructed photo-driven bioanode exhibited a photocurrent d. of over 100 μA cm-2 at a photon flux d. of 1500 μmol m-2 s-1.

Photosynthesis is a sustainable process for the conversion of light energy into chem. energy. Thylakoids in energy-transducing photosynthetic membranes are unique in biol. membranes because of their distinguished structure and compn. The quantum trapping efficiency of thylakoid membranes is appealing in photobioelectrochem. research. In this study, thylakoid membranes extd. from spinach are shown to communicate with a gold-nanoparticle-modified solid gold electrode (AuNP-Au) through a series of quinone derivs. Among these, para-benzoquinone (PBQ) is found to be the best sol. electron-transfer mediator, generating the highest photocurrent of approx. 130 μA cm-2 from water oxidn. under illumination. In addn., the photocurrent d. is investigated as a function of applied potential, the effect of light intensity, quinone concn., and amt. of thylakoid membrane. Finally, the source of photo-current is confirmed by using 3-(3,4-dichlorophenyl)-1,1-dimethylurea (known by its trade name, Diuron), an inhibitor of photosystem II, which decreases the total photocurrent by 50%.

Combination of thylakoid membranes (TMs) as photobiocatalysts with high surface area electroactive materials could hold great potentials for sustainable green solar energy conversion. We studied the orientated immobilization of TMs on high surface area graphene electrodes, which were fabricated by electroredn. of graphene oxide and simultaneous electrodeposition with further aminoaryl functionalization. We achieved the up-to-date highest performance under direct electron transfer conditions through a biocompatible wiring of TMs to graphene sheets. The photobiocurrent d. generated by the optimized mediator-free TM-based bioanodes yielded ≤5.24±0.50 μA/cm2. Photosystem II reaction center (RC) prepns. isolated from spinach (Spinacea oleracea) by the Nanba-Satoh procedure (O, Nanba, K. Satoh, 1987) are quite labile, even at 4° in the dark. Simple spectroscopic criteria were developed to characterize the native state of the material. Degrdn. of the RC results in (a) blue-shifting of the red-most absorption max., (b) a shift of the 77 K fluorescence max. from ∼682 nm to ∼670 nm, and (c) a shift of fluorescence lifetime components from 1.3-4 ns and >25 ns to ∼6-7 ns. Fluorescence properties at 77 K seem to be a more sensitive spectral indicator of the integrity of the material. The >25 ns lifetime component is assigned to P680+ pheophytin- recombination luminescence, which suggests a correlation between the obsd. spectral shifts and the photochem. competence of the prepn. Substitution of lauryl maltoside for Triton X-100 immediately after RC isolation stabilizes the RCs and suggests that Triton may be responsible for the instability.

A review with 121 refs. This article presents an overview of the essential aspects in the fabrication of silicon and some silicon/germanium nanostructures by metal-assisted chem. etching. First, the basic process and mechanism of metal-assisted chem. etching is introduced. Then, the various influences of the noble metal, the etchant, temp., illumination, and intrinsic properties of the silicon substrate (e.g., orientation, doping type, doping level) are presented. The anisotropic and the isotropic etching behaviors of silicon under various conditions are presented. Template-based metal-assisted chem. etching methods are introduced, including templates based on nanosphere lithog., anodic aluminum oxide masks, interference lithog., and block-copolymer masks. The metal-assisted chem. etching of other semiconductors is also introduced. A brief introduction to the application of Si nanostructures obtained by metal-assisted chem. etching is given, demonstrating the promising potential applications of metal-assisted chem. etching. Finally, some open questions in the understanding of metal-assisted chem. etching are compiled.

Ge surfaces were etched by means of metal-assisted chem. etching (MaCE). The behavior of the MaCE reaction in dild. H2O2 was compared with that of a conventional etchant of HF/H2O2/H2O mixt. (FPM). Herein we first report that a pyramidal structure on Ge (0 0 1) can be prepd. by MaCE in dil. H2O2 soln., without the use of HF. Contrastingly, an octagonal trench structure was prepd. by 4/5/1 FPM treatment of Ge (0 0 1) surface. This octagonal structure consisted of a square base, four large facets connected to the base, and other four small facets adjacent to the four large facets, which were considered to be (0 0 1), {1 1 0}, and {1 1 1}, resp. The octagonal trench was formed as a result of the difference in etch rate of Ge depending on the orientation: {1 0 0} > {1 1 0} > {1 1 1}. Ge surfaces treated by MaCE exhibited improved solar cell efficiency due to their improved light absorption, which led to significant increases in the cells' short circuit current and fill factor. The results suggest that optimized MaCE procedures can be an effective method to improve the performance of Ge-based photovoltaic devices.

Building low-power and high-d. circuits requires new devices, which can be based for example on single electron effects. Single electron transistors (SET), which can operate at room temp. (RT), are candidates with high potential for the post-CMOS era. However, their fabrication relies typically on a statistical fabrication of quantum dots or positioning of nanoparticles or mols. between predefined electrodes. These methods hamper a scaled-up fabrication of RT-SETs. Here, we present a route for reproducible fabrication of RT-SETs on the basis of field-emission scanning probe lithog. (FE-SPL) and cryogenic reactive ion etching. Due to the unique capabilities of our FE-SPL tool, enabling pre- and post-inspection of features, highly reliable patterning and precise feature alignment are obtained. The fabricated devices exhibit single electron effects at RT. A combination of this method with nanoimprint lithog. would enable a high throughput and reproducible way of RT-SET fabrication.

The thermal and mech. properties of a new neg. photoresist, SU-8, were characterized. The influence of curing conditions, such as baking temp., baking time and UV dosage, on the thermal and mech. properties of the resultant coatings was studied in detail. It was found that the glass-transition temp. (Tg) of the coatings was coincident with the baking temp. over the temp. range of 25 - 220° C for coatings being baked for just 20 min. However, the Tg reached a limiting value (about 240° C) once the crosslinking reaction was complete, and would not increase further with the baking temp. The peak temp. of the dimension vs. temp. plots, where heat shrinkage occurred, was about a factor of 1.16 times higher than the baking temp. for the temp. range studied. Both the Tg and the shrinkage temp. were affected by the baking time. The thermal expansion coeffs. (TEC), including the volumetric TEC (αv), the in-plane TEC (α1) and the out-of-plane TEC (α2), were measured by a pressure-vol.-temp. (PVT) app. and thermal-mech. analyzer (TMA). Great residual stress could be generated during the process, and the change in residual stress with the environmental humidity was investigated using vibrational holog. interferometry.

Production of reactive oxygen species by photosystem II

A review. Photosynthetic cleavage of water mols. to mol. oxygen is a crucial process for all aerobic life on the Earth. Light-driven oxidn. of water occurs in photosystem II (PSII), a pigment-protein complex embedded in the thylakoid membrane of plants, algae and cyanobacteria. Electron transport across the thylakoid membrane terminated by NADPH and ATP formation is inadvertently coupled with the formation of reactive oxygen species (ROS). ROS are mainly produced by photosystem I; however, under certain circumstances, PSII contributes to the overall formation of ROS in the thylakoid membrane. Under limitation of electron transport reaction between both photosystems, photoredn. of mol. oxygen by the reducing side of PSII generates a superoxide anion radical, its dismutation to hydrogen peroxide and the subsequent formation of a hydroxyl radical terminates the overall process of ROS formation on the PSII electron acceptor side. On the PSII electron donor side, partial or complete inhibition of enzymic activity of the water-splitting manganese complex is coupled with incomplete oxidn. of water to hydrogen peroxide. The review points out the mechanistic aspects in the prodn. of ROS on both the electron acceptor and electron donor side of PSII.

44
Quality Control of Photosystem II: The Mechanisms for Avoidance and Tolerance of Light and Heat Stresses are Closely Linked to Membrane Fluidity of the Thylakoids
Yamamoto Yasusi
Frontiers in plant science
(
2016
),
7
(
),
1136
ISSN:
1664-462X
.
When oxygenic photosynthetic organisms are exposed to excessive light and/or heat, Photosystem II is damaged and electron transport is blocked. In these events, reactive oxygen species, endogenous radicals and lipid peroxidation products generated by photochemical reaction and/or heat cause the damage. Regarding light stress, plants first dissipate excessive light energy captured by light-harvesting chlorophyll protein complexes as heat to avoid the hazards, but once light stress is unavoidable, they tolerate the stress by concentrating damage in a particular protein in photosystem II, i.e., the reaction-center binding D1 protein of Photosystem II. The damaged D1 is removed by specific proteases and replaced with a new copy produced through de novo synthesis (reversible photoinhibition). When light intensity becomes extremely high, irreversible aggregation of D1 occurs and thereby D1 turnover is prevented. Once the aggregated products accumulate in Photosystem II complexes, removal of them by proteases is difficult, and irreversible inhibition of Photosystem II takes place (irreversible photoinhibition). Important is that various aspects of both the reversible and irreversible photoinhibition are highly dependent on the membrane fluidity of the thylakoids. Heat stress-induced inactivation of photosystem II is an irreversible process, which may be also affected by the fluidity of the thylakoid membranes. Here I describe why the membrane fluidity is a key to regulate the avoidance and tolerance of Photosystem II on environmental stresses.

45
Photosystem-II damage and repair cycle in chloroplasts: what modulates the rate of photodamage ?
Melis
Trends in plant science
(
1999
),
4
(
4
),
130-135
ISSN:
.
Organisms that rely on oxygenic photosynthesis are subject to the effects of photo-oxidative damage, which impairs the function of photosystem-II (PSII). This phenomenon has the potential to lower rates of photosynthesis and diminish plant growth. Experimental evidence shows that the steady-state oxidation-reduction level of the primary quinone acceptor (QA) of PSII is the parameter that controls photodamage under a variety of physiological and environmental conditions. When QA is reduced, excitation energy at PSII is dissipated via a charge-recombination reaction. Such non-assimilatory dissipation of excitation generates singlet oxygen that might act to covalently modify the photochemical reaction center chlorophyll. Under steady-state photosynthesis conditions, the reduction state of QA increases linearly with irradiance, thereby causing a correspondingly linear increase in the probability of photodamage. It is concluded that there is a low probability that photodamage will occur when QA is oxidized and excitation energy is utilized in electron transport, and a significantly higher probability when QA is reduced in the course of steady-state photosynthesis.

In natural environments most bacteria live in biofilms embedded in complex matrixes of extracellular polymeric substances (EPS). This lifestyle is known to increase protection against environmental stress. Pseudomonas putida mt-2 harbours genes for the prodn. of at least four different EPS polysaccharides, including alginate and cellulose. Little is known about the functional properties of cellulose, while alginate attenuates the accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) caused by matric stress. By using mutants that are deficient in either alginate or cellulose prodn. we show that even cellulose attenuates the accumulation of matric stress-induced ROS for cells in biofilms. Further, both cellulose and alginate attenuate ROS generated through exposure to copper. Interestingly, the two EPS polysaccharides protect cells in both liq. culture and in biofilms against ROS caused by matric stress, indicating that cellulose and alginate do not need to be produced as an integral part of the biofilm lifestyle to provide tolerance towards environmental stressors.
